message: I'm about to learn "cross platform app development" using one of the frameworks out there but i'm a bit confused about which framework should i go for and which one is the best and most famous - i found Titanium , PhoneGap , Ionic

data.message: Platforms, platforms, platforms. Just go native.
I need to build an app that runs on multiple platforms =D

If you're going to build a quality application then its best to use the native method for each platform and develop individually for the specific API's. Frameworks do the job easier but them you won't have a quality app.
This is probably the 20th person who asks the same question, malko ya masreyeen GO NATIVE
should i have to learn 3 different platforms just to build a simple app =D , not an economical solution i think.

Yes you should, because you should be thinking long term and developing your skills, and not thinking in terms of "economical solution". You didn't even bother checking the previous replies on this forum to the EXACT SAME QUESTION
They're all variations of C++/C# basically. It takes an average of 1-2 weeks to port an app between android and iPhone native
I am starting too, did some research without actual experience , people suggest ionic framework + angularjs
Go Native, Don't go Cross Platform
are we talking about UI looking original and intuitive ? or about features which might not be supported correctly in the Cross Platform SDK ?
We are not talking about UI we are talking about using the SDKs in the cross platforms and performance issues on the output. beside the excessive usage of plugins to simulate the native apps.
Go Action Script 3 and Flash builder, Starling and feather framework... OR PhoneGap, using javascript html and css

Alright, So I found you the article that explains the difference between Native and Cross platform: 
http://www.sitepoint.com/native-vs-hybrid-app-development/

Going native or hybrid depends on several factors, for example 

-- Are you doing this app(s) only to learn? 
-- Are these apps commercial? do you have strict delivery dates?
-- Are you building performance-critical apps?? Or it is just some forms and data entry? 
-- Do you already have some skills that you can reuse? Native dev skills? HTML, JS?

If you can answer these questions, I can help determine what might be best for you.
Given the options you provided, without reading the comments,  I'd say PhoneGap and Ionic go together very well. Learn that.
